Comment: I started normally, expecting another boring beginning.
His move was very different to any I had expected, so I was getting ready for a fun and intersting game!
As we are usually taaught, I took the oppurtunity to take control of the center of the board.
He challenged me to a pawn swap but I didn't really want to let him get his queen out there so quickly. Now I had to think of a way to avoid this happening.
I ended up doing this, which proved to be very helpful for later. At that moment I was thinking that by doing that I had managed to prevent urgo from getting his knight easily to f6.
Now urgo was trying to advance his bishop, I decided that wanted to castle  on the queen's side, so I was deciding on either advancing my knight or bishop.
Obviously, I chose bishop, as I didn't want his bishop pinning my knight if I were to move it to c3 and I didn't want to move my knight to d2, as that would trap my bishop.
I guess urgo was simply advancing his pieces to get himself into a good position.
I decided that I may aswell advance my knight to give me more power around the center of the board.
When he did that, realised he wanted me to take his pawn so that he would be able to advance his knight.
To avoid taking his pawn I developed the pawn's protection by adding a bishop, which would be quite useful in the exchange.
When he did that, I noticed an oppurtunity to get a pawn up on him, unless he wanted to be checkmated.
I took the pawn because I had realised that if he took my knight, I would have a three move forced checkmate.
Unfortunately, urgo didn't realise that and fell for my trap. Now the fun began!
His only option was to move his king forwards.
Now I was happy that I had earlier moved my pawn to e5 as his king wouldn't have been able to escape down their now.
Helplessly, realising his mistake, urgo did the only move possible, preparing for the inevitable.
In just 9 moves I had beaten urgo, which is probably my quickest win!!
